awd_titl_txt: Reaction/Transport Behavior in the Synthesis of Functionally-Encoded Nanowires via the Geode Process
awd_abstract_narration:
The proposed project will investigate the chemical reactions and transport of chemical species involved in the synthesis of semiconductor nanowires on the interior surface of hollow, porous-walled microspheres. The use of these microspheres as nanowire growth substrates -- the "Geode process" -- promises to be a new platform for the scalable manufacturing of functional semiconductor nanowires for a range of applications (e.g., thermoelectrics, optical coatings, large-area electronics, etc.).  In the Geode process, hollow microspheres provide efficient gas transport and a large internal surface area for nanowire growth while preventing agglomeration and protecting the delicate liquid droplet that choreographs nanowire growth. The overarching objective of the proposed research is to gain a fundamental understanding of the underlying kinetics and transport phenomena to enable precise control of nanowire synthesis. The proposed collaboration between researchers from Georgia Tech and ALD NanoSolutions, Inc., has the potential of producing transformative results and enabling future commercial exploitation of this technology.

A novel experimental methodology will be employed. The specific objectives of the work are three-fold: (1) study the growth rate in steady state experiments as function of reaction conditions to quantify any mass and heat transfer limitations and optimize microsphere structure to mitigate adverse impacts on nanowire quality; (2) perform transient experiments that focus on detailed quantification of dopant concentration profiles in the nanowires when precursor gas mixtures are modulated; and (3) preliminarily quantify transport properties in a pilot-scale fluidized bed reactor to bridge the gap between lab-scale synthesis and scalable reactor technology.  In addition to training graduate students the research team plans to engage in societal and educational outreach via the Nanovation podcast, by including material related to nanomaterials in their undergraduate courses, and by developing a new hands-on fluidized bed activity for classroom use and K-12 outreach. These activities will highlight the potential of large scale nanomanufacturing and fluidized bed reactor technology specifically for advanced materials and device processing.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

pgm_ele.pgm_ele_name: Proc Sys, Reac Eng & Mol Therm

por.por_cntn:
The project advanced our ability to scalably fabricate semiconductor nanowires containing the nanoscale domains needed for a range of nanoelectronic devices and advanced materials. Prior to the advent of the Geode Process, it was possible to produce semiconductor nanowires at scale or with nanoscale control of composition, but not both. The Geode Process uses microcapsule powders as a high surface substrate for nanowire growth, allowing for an orders-of-magnitude increase in nanowire productivity while maintaining compositional control akin to conventional flat substrates (i.e., wafers). The Geode Process begins with the bulk emulsion templating of silica micro-capsules decorated on their interior surface with the metallic seed nanoparticles that drive nanowire growth. The resulting microcapsule powder is then placed inside a chemical vapor deposition reactor where precursor gases diffuse through the porous microcapsule wall, decompose at the metal nanoparticle, and drive nanowire nucleation and growth. After growth, depending on the application, nanowires can be harvested from the microcapsule or left inside. The following are the main outcomes of the project:

1. We demonstrated the basic concept of the Geode Process, including methods for stabilizing microcapsules during emulsion templating, separating microcapsules as a function of diameter, and preventing collapse upon drying.

2. We gained an understanding of the relevant reaction-diffusion phenomena of the Geode Process. The Geode Process operates in a reaction limited regime due to the relatively fast diffusion of nanowire growth precursors through the few micron microcapsule wall thickness and relatively slow reaction at the nanowire catalyst. As a result, it is possible to encode deep-sub-micron segments along the nanowire length, as confirmed by our experiments. We showed that these segments could be comprised of different dopants or semiconductors.

3. We developed a reaction-diffusion model to explore the role of key process parameters. It supports the reaction-limited nature of the Geode Process and elucidates more of the process space than could be done with experiment alone.

4. We have begun to understand the optical properties of individual microgeodes and microgeode ensembles/composites. Preliminary work shows that microgeode color can be tuned across the visible by varying nanowire diameter.

5. This project led to an MRI project to acquire a custom-designed powder chemical vapor deposition (CVD) and atomic layer deposition (ALD) reactor. This equipment will be in a new, campus-accessible powder processing lab and will play a central role in the continued development of the Geode Process.

Over the course of the project, two graduate students and five undergraduate students were trained to critically analyze data, interact on multidisciplinary teams, and disseminate their findings. Their understanding of scalable processes, nanomaterials, and electronics will support the development of technologies based on these materials/principles.

The learning gained from this work opens the door to new ?hyper-scalable? uses for nanoelectronic devices, including printed electronics or smart dust. Applications that rely on nanowire optical properties, such photoelectrocatalysis or building cooling, also stand to benefit.


Last Modified: 02/06/2023
Modified by: Michael A Filler

Image
  • Sequence of images showing a microcapsule powder in a vial, the same powder under an electron microscope, and a broken open microgeode following nanowire growth.
    Michael Filler
    Creative Commons
    Michael A Filler
    Geode Process
